description: Before everyone takes out trash, there are 100 units of trash in the house.
Jack wanted to take out 60 units of trash, and took out 30 units.

The tenants discussed their monthly trash report and proposed various solutions to optimize their trash disposal schedule based on individual patterns and trends, including a rotating schedule, a shared calendar, and a "trash swap" system.
conversation: Landlord

Ladies and gentlemen, let me give you the monthly trash report. John took out 35 units of trash. Kate took out 25 units of trash. Jack took out 30 units of trash. Emma took out 0 units of trash. Luke took out 10 units of trash.
John

Interesting report, Landlord. It seems we all had different strategies this month. I took out a bit less than I planned, but it looks like everyone else did their part. I'm curious, did anyone notice any particular patterns or trends in the amount of trash generated over the past few months? Maybe we can use that information to optimize our trash-taking-out schedule in the future.
Kate

Interesting observations, John. I agree that analyzing past trends could help us make more informed decisions in the future. For instance, I noticed that my trash generation tends to be higher during weeks when I cook more at home. Maybe we could consider a rotating schedule where each of us takes out a larger share of the trash during our high-production weeks. That way, we can minimize the overall time spent on trash disposal while ensuring that the workload is evenly distributed.
Emma

That's an excellent idea, Kate. I've also noticed that my trash generation tends to be higher when I have guests over. Perhaps we could create a shared calendar where we can all input our high-production weeks and plan accordingly. This way, we can coordinate our trash-taking-out schedules to minimize the overall time spent on it.
Jack

I've also noticed that my trash generation tends to be higher when I work from home. Maybe we could consider a system where we take turns having "trash weeks," where each of us is responsible for taking out a larger share of the trash during their designated week. This way, we can spread out the workload and minimize the overall time spent on trash disposal.
Luke

I've also noticed that my trash generation tends to be higher during weekends when I entertain guests or have more leisure activities. Perhaps we could consider implementing a "trash swap" system, where we trade taking out extra trash during our high-production weeks in exchange for someone else taking out less during their low-production weeks. This way, we can ensure that the workload is evenly distributed and minimize the overall time spent on trash disposal.
Kate

That's a great suggestion, Luke. A trash swap system could be an effective way to distribute the workload evenly while minimizing the overall time spent on trash disposal. I think we're all on the same page about the importance of analyzing past trends and communicating with each other to optimize our trash-taking-out schedule. Let's give this new system a try and see how it goes.
